plist.p: Good morning, thank you for coming this morning. Here is the agenda of today. I will first start going with the financial results and giving you an overview of the principal achievements for the last year. Then I will hand over, as always, to Andy for the detailed financial review and for the guidance for next year. And then I will get back and I will talk about how we are making Vodafone a stronger and more competitive company and how is this turning into better returns for our shareholders. And then I will be joined by the regional COOs – Andy and I will be joined by the regional COOs for questions.

So let's start with the overview of the results. Service revenues were £14.7 billion, down 1.6% on an organic basis in 2010. However, in Q4, revenue declined only 0.2%, which is the best quarterly growth figure in the year and the second sequential quarterly improvement driven once again mostly by mobile data and by fixed line performance.

Looking at our regions, you can see Europe, where revenue declined 1.7% in Q4, which is 1.5 percentage point better than Q3. In Africa and Central Europe, revenue returned actually to growth in Q4 at 2.4%, helped by growth in Vodafone and in Turkey. In Asia Pacific and the Middle East, revenue grew for the whole year at 9.8% with India as always being the major driver here and a slightly lower – slower level of growth in Q4, as expected, as we went through the anniversary of Indus Towers.

EBITDA reached 14.7 billion, increasing by 1.7% on reported basis with the group EBITDA margins slightly above 33.1%, declining very much in line with our expectations as we set them out last November. Operating profit at 11.5 billion was ahead of guidance as I will come onto in a moment, is down 2.5% reflecting the overall recession.

In contrast, free cash flow was pretty good at 7.2 billion. This is our second highest ever cash flow level, ahead of guidance and up 26.5%. I think this reflects the focus that the company has got on free cash flow generation in the year and the benefit of the working capital program that I announced six month or one year ago.

Adjusted EPS at 16.11 was down 6.2% on last year, but up 6.6 on an underlying basis. The board has recommended a final dividend of 5.65p, making the total dividends for the year 8.31, up 7%. We have also announced today a 3-year dividend growth target, which will mean that we intend to raise dividends per share by 7% in each of the next 3 years.

So we have exceeded guidance. Guidance was set at 11.8 billion in terms of adjusted operating profit last May. We then upgraded it to 11.4 – 11.8 in February and the actual result was 11.9 billion, once we restate for guidance FX and for 200 million of Alltel restructuring cost.

And in terms of free cash flow, we have exceeded our range substantially at 7.3 on guidance FX levels. And I want to stress that this is after having invested 6.2 billion in CapEx again. So we have maintained our CapEx level and we are not producing cash flow by reducing CapEx.
Before I hand over to Andy, I would like to very quickly go through the 5 key achievements of the year, which I will explain in more detail when I come back after Andy's presentation.

So what have we achieved in the last 12 months? I think 5 important things. First, we have increased the group commercial focus, ensuring that our offers are competitive, investing in market share gains where we can make money and funding this through structural cost reductions and of course, also executing on the turnaround where we had to do turnarounds.

Second during the year we have improved our revenue mix, reducing our reliance on what I would call mature European mobile voice, and increasing revenue from consumer and business data services, fixed broadband and lower priced emerging market voice.
Third, we have used our strong free cash flow generation to maintain investment in network capacity and network quality, which we think is strategic for the future.

Fourth, we have made significant changes, internal changes at Vodafone in terms of simplifying the organization, reducing overhead and redirecting rewards for management to reward appropriate customer oriented and market share oriented behaviors. And as a result, we have accelerated our transformation that will enable us to continue to generate good cash flow to support the dividend growth target that we have announced today.
Now, these are the 5 key themes that we will review in more detail later. Let me now hand over to Andy for the financial review.

Right. Good morning and thank you, Vittorio. So, just to go through the numbers in a little bit more detail, first of all, the total revenue number 44.5 billion for the year, that was an 8.4% headline increase. And if you, within that on the chart on the right, you can see about 5 percentage points of it came from FX, about 5 percentages points of it came from M&A, particularly the increased stake in Vodacom and that gave us an underlying reduction of 2.3%.

If you look at the equivalent on service revenue, the numbers were fairly similar, the pattern was fairly similar. The underlying service revenue decline on the service revenue basis was minus1.6%. So, a bit worse than that at the start of the year but improving generally as we got through the balance of the year.

Included in those numbers is £4 billion of data revenues, which is the first time that we have hit the 4 billion number on the data front. In terms of the EBITDA, as Vittorio said, 14.7 billion. You can see on the chart on the bottom right that is an underlying reduction of about 7%, but with improvements from foreign exchange and M&A, has come to a reported 1.7% increase with margins around 2 percentage points down year-on-year, which is in line with what we had expected. Adjusted operating profit therefore at 11.5.

Financing costs are – I will come on to these a little bit more detail later, are down quite significantly year-on-year. The underlying tax rate is fairly similar year-on-year. Two big items down below just to focus upon those. One, an impairment charge, the 2.1 billion, but secondly a tax credit of roughly 2.3 billion in total.

Impairment charge is in relation primarily to India, where in recognition of the increasing intensity in the market number of competitors and the recent pricing changes, we've decided that we should take a 2.3 billion impairment charge offset in part by a 200 million release of a previous impairment charge or part of a previous impairment charge for Turkey. So the net number is 2.1, of which 2.3 is India.

The 2.274 number then below that is very largely, I think it's 2.1 billion of that, is the final resolution of one of the long-standing tax disputes. So this is one where we have agreed in Germany tax losses of €15 billion. That is meaning in accounting terms that we are able to take a credit here of 2.1 billion being the elimination of the provisions we previously held in actually setting up the small asset.

On the other hand, in a cash sense, what this means is that roughly 200 million a year of cash tax saving that we have been enjoying for the last several years, we will now continue to enjoy for many years going forwards. So overall, 8.6 billion profit for the period after those two items. The earnings per share at 16.11p is, if one reverses out another one-off tax item from the previous year and deals with them basically on equivalent basis, is up by 6.6%.

So let's just move then onto the regions and first of all Europe. So top left chart here is showing the trend on service revenues over the 4 quarters of last year. You can see we started the period with revenues about 4.5 percentage point back. We have exited the year on published numbers at about a 1.7% run rate. There is a small benefit to do with some loyalty accounting in Italy in the last quarter. If we strip that out, the last quarter rather than being minus 1.7, will be minus 2.4 for Europe. But nonetheless even with that adjustment, the overall progression there is about a percentage point of achievement per quarter.

That same accounting adjustment means that the group service revenue decline in the fourth quarter of minus 0.2, was actually minus 0.6. And it is entirely an impact in the quarter, we essentially slightly over-accrued in earlier quarters released than the last quarter. So there is no impact on the full year basis.

So the overall trend is improving and I'll come on to this on the next slide, but broadly we're seeing this across most products, and we're seeing this across most customer segments. Data has been strong in Europe clearly as it has been across the rest of the group, so 19% increase in data revenues. I'm particularly pleased with the focus upon mobile Internet, where we've seen revenues up by 37% year-on-year.

Fixed line has also been an area of big focus with revenues there up about 6% and European broadband customer base now up at 5.4 billion. Chart on the bottom left shows the continuing change in the mix of the revenue stream within Europe, so 38% of the revenues now are coming from products other than the historic voice products.

The drivers behind those revenues then, top left chart here is on outgoing voice. So in red on the top, you can see the total volume of minutes just gradually improving quarter-by-quarter up 4% fourth quarter on fourth quarter, against the backdrop in grey of prices still coming down about 11% per minute as we have experienced for many quarters.

On the top right, you can see the roaming trends. So the roaming trends four quarters ago, we were about 17 percentage point back. That has improved considerably and was 4.5 percentage point back on the fourth quarter. And on the bottom left, the enterprise business about 30% of our European business, again was back 5, 6% at the start of the year and has exited the year at just under 2%. And then finally on the right hand side, data revenues at 19%, so increase has consistently being very strong in the period. And in fact we are now getting more data revenues from the consumer segment than from the business segment.

Moving then on to cost, two slides here. The first £1 billion that we announced in 2008, we have now delivered and there's a walk there at the top of how that's impacted the overall cost base. On the bottom left is the blue wheel circle, which shows that the costs have come out pretty much across the business, all the major operating businesses and out of the center as well. And just highlighted on the bottom right one or two particular features of this, head count in the European region is down 2,300 year-on-year, about a 6% reduction. Secondly, in independent benchmarking of the efficiency of our data networks of the top 10 most efficient networks, Vodafone has 7.

Thirdly, in terms of what we've been doing over the last two to three years on supply chain, centralization of that, we're now again benchmarking very favorably in buying patterns against equivalent buyers. And fourthly, our focus in the network area of bringing more transmission in-house and getting the cost efficiencies there has changed substantially the profile of the transmission that is now under our own control rather than payments to third parties.

So we are now onto the next billion that we talked about a short while ago. The good news is we have identified the target areas, we've got the teams up, they are mobilized and they are working on these broadly sort of 4 areas. One of course the streamlining, looking at things like the product launch processes and making sure those are ever more efficient.

Secondly what can we either outsource or offshore, captive offshore a number of initiatives on that front. Thirdly standardization of sort of best practice, sort of going into new areas. Handset logistics, we're looking closely at in this point in time. And then finally, deeper integration of the network, which is an ongoing journey but there is more that we are doing on that front.

So the intent here is that that billion, roughly half of it we think we need to do because it'll lead to offset volume and inflationary increases but the other half billion should be there either for commercial reinvestment or to flow through to the bottom line. So, news there is that is now in progress and underway.

Moving then on to margins in Europe, the average organic revenues, service revenues down about 3.5 percentage points, the margin was actually contained to a 1 percentage point drop during the year, so 37.6 down to 36.6. And just doing very quickly the walk across the chart here, the biggest impact has been on our direct contribution.

So the impact of the revenues has taken about 1.3 percentage points off the margin. But if you look at the next two blocks, you can see that the work we've done on taking cost out of the business has more than funded the additional investment we have made in acquiring or retaining more customers and we have put more money in, in the second half of the year which is pretty well getting us back to run rates we were at previously to make sure that we are really gaining market share as much as we can do.

There is then a small impact from the changing mix between the fixed and the mobile businesses. So the fixed business with about a 14% margin, the mobile businesses with margins in the high 30s. That takes about 0.2 off the margin and then the small FX benefit and we get to the 36.6 full year number for the region.

So change of regions, Africa and Central Europe back to growth, I think is the headline here. After three quarters with the year-on-year run rate being negative, we have now got a fourth quarter at plus 2.4. And really, I think, there are sort of 3 key things in this. First of all, Turkey, where the turnaround is definitely gaining momentum. In the fourth quarter, we were actually up 31% on revenues compared with the fourth quarter of a year ago, albeit with a slightly negative EBITDA overall, but the traction there is palpable.

In South Africa, secondly, performance of the business there – they announced their results yesterday, very strong and overall growth in revenues around the 7% level and with margins slightly improving during the period.

And then thirdly, the Central European markets, where I think the general macroeconomic environment has been as tough as we have seen anywhere in the group. The good news is there that despite the revenues being a bit weaker, the focus that the businesses have had on the cost side has actually held up the margins pretty well. And collectively including Poland, the free cash flow generation from those markets is still around 0.5 billion sterling.

On the top right hand side, you can see the margin walk for the region which is down about two percentage points with some mix effects, some extra investment in Turkey in order to facilitate the turnaround offset in part by the improved margin in South Africa.

So on to Asia Pacific and Middle East, continued growth here, so all 4 quarters we saw positive trends on revenues, slightly lower level in the fourth quarter, but bear in mind that the previous quarters had the benefit of no comparative for Indus Towers, whereas the fourth quarter is the first time that we have had Indus in the comparable numbers for the previous year.

So the overall numbers here are quite significantly influenced by India. Vittorio will talk to this in a little bit more detail later, but essentially notwithstanding the very tough pricing environment, the business has been performing extremely well, has been gaining market share, is now over 100 million customers and is operating very well.

In Egypt, the customer growth continues strongly, revenues fairly stable year-on-year and margin still holding up well at around the 50% level. And then thirdly in Australia, the integration of the joint venture business is going absolutely to plan and at the same time we are seeing the revenue growth happening there. So, overall good progress in Australia.

On the margin, walk for this region on the top right, you can see about 2 percentage point of decline on the margin. The most significant feature of this actually is a mix effect because India is growing disproportionately and has a lower than average margin for the region, that is actually just mathematically taking the margin down a bit. And then the rest of it is just small changes in margin across a number of the other businesses.

Verizon Wireless numbers were published 2 or 3 weeks ago. So this is largely in the public domain already. Key here I think is another strong performance with revenues growing 5 or 6%, slightly tougher pricing environment with all you can eat plans being prevalent but Verizon Wireless pushing very, very hard on the data products and now who's got a customer base of around 93 million customers.

On the top right, you can see the sort of cash proxy of the EBITDA less the CapEx, which is now running at the rate in one quarter of $4.6 billion. So 1.5 billion per month and the debt levels in Verizon Wireless are now heading towards and down towards $20 billion with some proceeds due shortly from some of the properties that are being divested.

So back up on to group metrics, adjusted operating profit broadly unchanged year-on-year, 11.8 for the previous year, 11.5 this year, reduction primarily from EBITDA in Europe, increase from foreign exchange and a slightly bigger contribution from Verizon Wireless.

On the financing costs, as said earlier, we've seen a good reduction in financing costs. So the top line here we've seen, sort of what I call the pure financing costs, have reduced from 1.1 billion to 0.9 billion. And you can see down on the very bottom line here that the average cost of debt has now dropped below 4%, which we believe is the lowest of any global telco.

In the second line on here, mark-to-market adjustments, we had a more cost to book last year, previous year I should say, and those have hence reduced and the dividends and interest on tax are fairly constant. So overall, the adjusted net financing costs are actually down by 400 million from 1.3 to 0.9 billion and we're very comfortable with our debt position going forwards and have largely fixed for next year.

So the effective tax rate, there was at a headline level very little difference between the 2 years, the year we just finished was 24.0%, the year before underlying was 24.5. In the year before however, we had one tax settlement that gave us a one-off of 7 or 8 percentage point benefit. So we actually reported a very low tax charge the previous year, but that was because of a one-off item and the underlying, as I say, was very, very similar.

We've talked about the big settlement in Germany, just on the other cases, the CFC case. We're now going through a process of actually going through all the details and having those compared with the various court rulings, so that is a process which is ongoing. And in terms of the India tax case, the ball at the moment is very much in the court of the tax authorities there, who have got to form a view as to whether they think they have got the jurisdiction on this matter. And we expect to hear back from them over the coming weeks on that so, there is no change at this point in time. And overall, it remains our intent to target about a mid-20 effective tax rate going forwards.

So capital investment, this chart is done at constant FX, so 6.2 billion of investment in both years. Let me just draw out three things here. The investment in Europe is basically held at previous levels. We are very, very focused upon building out our data networks and given the prodigious cash flow from the rest of the business, we have absolutely continued to focus on that.

Secondly, in the Africa and Central Europe region, you can see that the overall level of spend has increased. There are two primary reasons for that. The first is that in the previous year, we only had the Vodacom numbers in at a 50% level because of our ownership at that time, whereas in the most recent year, they are in at 100%. That is about a 250 million increase purely because of the accounting. Secondly, in Turkey we have invested year-on-year about 150 million more as part of the turnaround plan.

The other one then finally on here is on India, where you can see the CapEx level has decreased quite markedly over that period of time. So we did spend 1.4 billion a year or ago and spent 0.8 billion last year. That is very much a focus upon sharing, using the tower company and is a focus upon network management and really making sure we're getting the most out of our networks. So overall, those sorts of levels we are believing will be similar to our levels in the year that we are now just entering.

Free cash flow, 7.2 billion up from 5.7 a year previously, the second highest I think we have had in our history in the middle of a recession. So briefly the walk on this, a reduction from the slightly lower EBITDA, working capital is on here at 0.9, we actually generated 0.7 of it in the year and the previous year we had a minus 0.2, which obviously doesn't reverse, so about 0.7 of benefit during year.

The CapEx interest, the tax collectively, sort of broadly evened each other out. Dividends was up quite significantly and that is pretty much exclusively the U.S. three factors. One, we received some dividend in this last year that would otherwise have been paid in the previous year. We received secondly more dividend because of the agreement we reached at the time of the Alltel deal to slightly boost the level of tax dividends. And thirdly, the increased level of profitability of the business has increased the dividend so that we can pay the tax on it.

And then finally on here, FX, which has nudged us up to the 7.2 number. So overall, 13.8p per share of free cash flow generation. Although to be clear, of that 7.2 about 0.7 is coming from working capital, 6.5 without the working capital and whilst we will do some more working capital next year, that is why we are more focused on the 6.5 number in our forward guidance on the free cash flow for the year we're just in.

So on net debt, started the year at 34 billion, finished the year at 33 billion. The simple story there is we generated 7 billion of free cash flow. We paid 4 billion out by way of dividends. We paid roughly 3 billion for M&A, particularly the Vodacom acquisition and we had a 1 billion benefit from foreign exchange. Overall, down 1 billion, which is consistent with our single A, low single A credit rating target.

So looking forwards onto – into the '10 – '11 year, the two numerical guidance reference points, the profit we're aiming to have in the 11.2 to 12.0 billion range and the free cash flow to be in excess of £6.5 billion. So within that, our assumption is that we will see some improvement in the economies in which we are operating, we'll be at still at fairly low rates. We will see continuing growth in markets like India, purely because of the penetration potential there.

So if we look at our own business, we are saying at some stage during next year, more second half than first half, we would expect to return back to revenue growth. Secondly, we're saying that the margins which went down 2 percentage points last year, we would expect that rate in reduction to significantly improve next year, again more second half than first half, but as the cost programs come to pare and as the revenue trend improves, we would expect that to significantly improve. Thirdly on CapEx, we expect that to be at similar levels to last year and finally all of this is on the assumption, which is not easy to be accurate on, that the FX rates are roughly 1.15 for the euro and 1.50 for the dollar.

So in summary, before I hand back to Vittorio, there are for me sort of 4 things that stand out here. One, we have got the revenue trends bit-by-bit heading in the right direction. Secondly, the focus we have had upon cost is absolutely gaining momentum and is now starting to show through in the numbers. Thirdly, the cash generation and cash conversion has been significant, particularly not just what we've done with the cost of working capital has I think been a big step forwards. And finally, our funding is very efficient and we have got very low costs of debt.
So with that, I will hand back to Vittorio.

Thank you and now I would like to go back to my key theme for today, which is a stronger Vodafone. And I will do that just going through the 5 key achievements of last year. So let me start by looking at our key operating companies and how we have increased the commercial focus in all of them and of course conducted a turnaround where we needed to do turnarounds.

Let me start with Germany. In Germany, our trends have improved 1.2 percentage points to a minus 1.6%. This is the second successive quarterly improvement in an economy, which is more stable than others, but also in a fairly aggressive market. Here we have voice still pretty weak. We have got an incredibly good performance as you can see in the chart, 27% in data growth, this is PC connectivity but also, as Andy have said, mobile Internet really going well, 500,000 SuperFlat customers. You might remember, I mentioned SuperFlat for the first time 12 to 18 months ago, and further improvements in enterprise.

Total EBITDA margins declined a couple of percentage points to 39%, but mobile EBITDA margins remain in the high 40s. We had said that we would increase commercial spend in the second half of the year. We anticipated that in November. This has been funded fully by cost reduction. During the year, we have reduced the head count in Germany by 600 people and we have reduced OpEx by 2%. This increased spending has gone into of course higher ARPU services, smartphones, netbooks, the SuperFlat tariffs.

In Germany, going ahead, we need to do more on the cost front and we need to do more on the commercial portfolio front. On the cost front, this year we have completed the integration of Arcor and Vodafone, now we have a fully integrated company, fixed and mobile. We are about now to start a second restructuring, which is meant to create a more efficient construction for the merged entity.

On Italy – in Italy the growth has slowed, again reflecting two things. A weaker economy but also price competition, which is being led by our main competitor in Italy, price competition to which we always respond in Italy.

Looking at the revenue trends closely, you can see data, fixed line and enterprise revenue was pretty good but these, as you can see in the chart in the lower part of the chart, this has been partially offset by weaker revenues in the prepaid segment where we are firmly defending our market share in the market.

In this context, I think it's pretty remarkable that our EBITDA has gone up 1 percentage point this year. The overall increased revenue and the good work done on cost has allowed us to invest in fixed broadband, in customer care and in advertising in the year.

Looking forward, we continue to push in Italy on smartphones. We will make more investments in online and customer care and we'll continue to bid of course on our fixed broadband and on our enterprise effort. I would say, in general, it seems to me that the performance in Italy has been pretty good in the year.

Spain, Spain – the Spanish economy as we all know continues to remain weak with rather high unemployment levels and also the competitive intensity in Spain has increased due to the fact that our main competitor has raise commercial spending in the second half.

In this context, I cannot say that I am happy but I can say that I am somewhat satisfied that we have slightly improved our rate of decline in Q4 to around minus 6.2%, as you see in the chart, with very good fixed growth remaining at around 80% and that some weakness in data growth which is more linked to some regulatory change which is not allowing any more certain promotions that we used to do in the past. But I would say nothing substantial in the market other than this thing. In this context, the 0.8 percentage points decline in margin in Spain represent, in my view, a pretty good achievement by our local management in a year where revenues have declined 8%. We have taken strong management actions on overhead and on commercial efficiency and this I think has mitigated in a quite visible way, the margin decline in Spain.

Going ahead, good success of Tarifas Planas. We continue to invest there. We continue to invest in fixed broadband and we will try to continue to drive converged services in Spain. Overall, a challenging environment in Spain for '09 – '10, but Vodafone Spain is a performing unit.
Moving to the U.K., in the U.K. revenue in Q4 declined 2.6%, which is a 2.3 percentage point improvement on Q3 and again the second successive improvement in quarterly growth trends.

In U.K., we've got a very good performance of contract net adds, 256,000, pretty stable in the last three quarters – in the quarter. We are generating in the U.K. benefits substantially out of better pricing, out of more – better and more visible advertising, complete smartphone line-up, iPhone here clearly playing a role. And this has led us to be for the first time in 2 years MNP positive in the quarter.

EBITDA margins declined 2.7 percentage points in the year. In the context of the revenue decline of 5%, the U.K. management team has clearly taken cost as a priority. We've reduced the U.K. FTEs by 1,400 in the year, which corresponds to about 14% of the U.K. workforce.

Looking to next year, we need to continue in the U.K. to work on the turnaround, basically focusing on 3 things. Network advantage, which is I think publicly recognized as you have read in the press by a number of independent entities. Driving the smartphone take-up, it's not on the chart, I think in the last quarter the data growth in the U.K. was 33, 32.8%. Again the highest in Europe, so pretty good. And of course we have to work on efficiency and continue to work on efficiency. In the U.K., we will launch this year the Vodafone One Net, which is the converged service for enterprise.

And one final thing that I want to mention about the U.K. because I'm very proud, we are working on the turnaround, but we are also working on innovation. We just got a deal with Centrica for 1 million meters machine-to-machine deal. This is probably the largest in Europe. So I'm confident the U.K. will continue on its turnaround and I'm also glad to see that we're working on innovation and the new important things for the future.

India, now India, Andy have – has said that we have made good commercial progress in the past 12 month in what I would call a dynamic or maybe more appropriately, a price aggressive environment. In Q4 service revenue increased 7%, which is more or less the same amount of the previous quarter. So we delivered 2 successive quarters of growth, sequential growth, after the price reduction have taken place and we have passed the 100 million customers mark in the same period.

Market share trends, we have increased as you can see at the bottom, in the bottom part of the chart. We have increased our share of the top 4 large players by more than 1 percentage point in one year with – and this is an important point for your consideration about the future in India – with already 75% of our customers on the new tariff plans. So I think this is pretty good.

EBITDA margins fell 0.8 percentage points. We absorbed in this period, the impact of the launch of the 6 new circles and Indus Tower. But more importantly, we have moved in India to be – from being cash negative to being cash positive in the second part of the year.

And also EBITDA margins in the last part of the year have been better than in the equivalent period of the previous year. So in India, I would say that our strategy, which was really highly visible brand, good distribution and competitive pricing, is working.

If I look back to the acquisition days, we – I think we have achieved quite a bit since 2007. We have grown from a number 3 player in the market to a number 2 player in the market. We have created Indus Tower, which is the largest tower company in the world. And we have added 72 million customers in the period.

In light of these achievement, clearly the impairment that we announced today that Andy has commented before, is what I would call, a disappointing but necessary and I would say almost inevitable step which follows the addition of 6 new competitors – nationwide competitors. In reality, it's 8 new and 120 licenses, 1 year after our acquisition and the subsequent price reductions – dramatic price reductions, which have taken place last year. But from an operational perspective and from a market perspective, India is a very performing unit.

Moving to South Africa. In South Africa, growth trends have – are improving but also the competitive intensity is improving in the market. Nevertheless, as announced yesterday, Vodacom continues to grow revenue market share in the market particularly focusing on mobile data. Elsewhere within the South African portfolio, competition and I would say economic challenges most noticeably in the DRC have slowed the growth rate of the company in Q4.

EBITDA margins continue to be flat with benefits coming from cost savings and reduced license fees. Looking ahead, I would say, Vodacom will continue with the current strategy, which is strategy of leadership in mobile broadband, high quality data network. And actually will make some investments in fiber in order to reduce the cost of carrying this data and to of course improve the experience of the customers. Yesterday, also Vodacom announced a revised dividend policy, which recognizes the low gearing that they have.

Now final case of the turnaround, Turkey. In Q4 as you can see in the chart, the revenue growth in Turkey was at 31%. In Turkey, we have gained about 2 percentage points of market share in 3 quarters in an economy, which today is improving again. EBITDA was roughly nil, which was expected. So, I would say that our turnaround strategy, which was really combining more price competitive offers, a better network and a controlled distribution, which I think I declared 12 to 18 month ago, is really helping us. We now have 50% – we have got 50% net add shares in the market and we have been mobile number portability positive throughout the whole year.

What can we expect from Turkey looking ahead? We expect, basically to continue with the same strategy, revenue growth in the, I would say high single digit for the year. And of course we want to return to profitability although it is likely that in this year, it will not be a very high one.

In summary, having reviewed the first topic, I think that our strong commercial focus is generating improving strength across all the market, but also that Vodafone today is a stronger Vodafone than 12 month ago in both mature Europe and in emerging economies.

Let me move to the second important topic of our strengthening Vodafone theme. In the past 12 month, we have continued to push voice data, mobile data, fixed broadband services to enterprise and of course growth into emerging markets. This is helping us to drive away the mix of our revenues, away from what I would call mature, relatively higher priced European voice into new services, data services, which in Europe tend to be priced lower than in most parts of the world and of course grow in emerging markets.

As you can see from the chart, now today we already generate 58% of our revenues from these new services, lower priced voice market and 42% out of European mobile voice. This is strategic I think to portray and to have a Vodafone which has a mix of revenues more future proof given the trends in the market. How are we going to drive this? Well, first of all of course data, as you can see in the chart, data penetration today is about 34% with regular data subscribers, people who pay subscription at 14% of our base in Europe. Our goal is to drive this penetration north of 50% within 3 years including the replacement of old infotainment services with new data services.

Smartphones are key in this migration. Smartphones today, you see in the second line or in third line actually, they represent 30% in the last quarter of our sales mix. We want to drive this to 70% so that we can go from 11% of people having a smartphone regular usage to above 35.

Often I am asked, Vittorio, what is the profitability of the spend? And I have to tell you that we track the data shift profitability on a monthly basis and the average profitability of smartphones is absolutely in line with our average profitability. There is a higher initial cost but on a pre-post basis there is also higher ARPU and higher margins. And of course you have to keep in mind that the more smartphones are coming into the market and now the choice is becoming really rich, the more we can get deeper into the customer base, so drive those 70 and 35, with products that have a lower initial cost and better profitability for us.

If you look at the other side of the equation, dongles, data card, as I would say in few – in few minutes, they have different economics, so a small upfront cost almost nothing. And of course they use the network much more. But if you combine the 2 things, again the profitability is in line with the average profitability. So what I can say is that this strategy of increasing the 2 bottom parts of the bar is not coming at a cost or actually is delivering the same profitability that we have today.

The second way we'll drive the shift is of course the fixed burden. I will talk about it in few moments, but clear – here clearly the strategy is to go there where it makes sense from an economical point of view.

We are working on services. Services for enterprise, the Vodafone One Net, international services through Vodafone Global Enterprise, consumer services, Vodafone 360, slightly less than half a million users today on Vodafone 360 and of course machine-to-machine and all the other innovation.

Now in parallel, emerging markets continue to grow. Today they continue to grow mostly in voice, but data penetration is the next thing and data penetration today in emerging markets is only 5%. And if I have to judge from markets like South Africa, as soon as you create the right – you have the right networks and the right smartphones or devices, there is an opportunity in data there.
So, second point we'll continue to drive towards a total communication company and I would call it a more geographically balanced and future proof mix, 42% exposure to European mature mobile voice.

Fixed broadband, fixed broadband is a part of our strategy. I stated 18 month ago that we wanted to become a leading provider of total communication across Europe, where we could make economic sense of it. In order to assess whether we can make economic sense of it, we look at competitors and alternative providers. We look at price levels and we look at regulation. Whether we need to own or not own assets fundamentally depends on the competitors' openness to cooperation and on regulation. And so for example in Germany, Spain, Portugal, Italy, we own some asset and in U.K. and in Ireland we don't or in Greece in a different way, we don't. In the past 2 years we have integrated Tele2, we have integrated the minorities of Arcor and we have expanded our coverage in terms of central offices, in terms of geographic coverage to something, which is about 60% in the markets where we operate on average.

I would say that our strategy today is working. As you can see in the chart, 5.4 million customers across Europe, 3 billion of revenues, brand has been successfully extended to fixed services where we have done it. And of course the short-term goal, from a financial point of view we were cash consumptive, now we are cash neutral. We want to turn the fixed broadband business into a cash positive unit for us.

So we regularly check our network performance. We actually see some improvements. We are pleased to report some improvements and we are also pleased to see that these are appreciated also publicly, by independent parties.

In 2009-10 we have added 3,500 sites. We continue to add HSPA higher versions, which improve this type of efficiency and customer experience. We now have a 3G outdoor coverage, which is probably between 80 and 95% in each – across the different European countries. We will continue to invest in this direction.

So overall I would say I remain comfortable with our CapEx levels in Europe and I am convinced that this is the appropriate level for both the customers and our financial discipline – internal financial discipline.

Fourth element of work for the last 12 to 18 month, a change in Vodafone's pro-forma culture. My objective here has been and is very clear. I want to create a leaner, more competitive and more customer oriented culture within Vodafone and I want to reward the behaviors that are consistent with these things.

So what we have done? We have made Vodafone leaner and simpler by sliming down the corporate functions by about 200 people if you count internal and contractors. We have changed about – we just finished actually – about 16% of the top teams across the top 300 of Vodafone.

We have increased spans and reduced layers to make the organization flatter and quicker. And of course by doing this, we have reduced complexity and increased the efficiency. We also have simplified some responsibilities between group and operating functions, clarifying in a very punctual way, what are the responsibilities for delivery and of course avoiding and eliminating cost duplications across the group.

In 2010-11, we also have increased more the level of which with which we can vary rewards for managers depending on competitive results and relative market share. So that to put it in a simple way, the full bonus can not be earned just by hitting a budget or a financial projection, but there is a large component which is really competition driven. And we have included 3 cash flow targets in the long-term incentives for all managers, so that yearly gains must be sustainable over the period.

And finally in order to enforce the outward looking culture, we have adopted as major customer support, not to the customer satisfaction but rather the net promoter score which is a much more powerful measure that enables us to compare not just with the Telefónicas of this word but also with the new players coming from the IP space.

So what does all of this mean for our shareholders? It means a company-wide focus on performance and a company-wide focus on generating a sustainable free cash flow that will enable to improve our shareholders return.

In November '08, I set out together with Andy a medium term objective that Vodafone would generate between 5 and £6 billion per year of free cash. In today's terms, this would be 5.5 to 6.5. Today, 18 months later, we have announced a new medium-term target. We now expect our annual free cash flow to be between 6 and 7 billion per annum over the next 3 years.

Now, why are we confident that we can achieve this? If you look at the business in '09, '10 we have made an operating cash flow investment in 4 areas: Turkey, India, Ghana and Qatar and this is about £600 million. And as I've said, we are cash neutral on the fixed business. As we move along with improvement in those businesses and in pushing them towards cash generation, this will clearly benefit the overall company position at a time where the working capital improvement after a couple of years should start fading out.

So this growth will help us sustain higher free cash flow and higher free cash flow will help supporting growth in EPS of at least 7% per annum without cutting back on investments, which we do believe are strategic for the future.

So in conclusion, I think today we have a stronger Vodafone. We have strengthened Vodafone commercially. We have increased efficiency and we are executing on turnarounds. We're – we've decreased our reliance and we continue to decrease our reliance on mature European mobile voice and focus more and more on new services and emerging economies and data. We delivered our financial performance ahead of guidance and we have increased our target for sustainable free cash flow generations. And this turns into an intention to increase dividends per share for our shareholders by 7% at least each year for the last year and for each of the next 3 years.
